body:
Oh, sorry, I didn‚Äôt understand you meant implementing our own that way! That explains why what you wrote differed from what I remembered reading in Chromium‚Äôs source :P

It should probably be named differently, though, to avoid confusion, since the implementation you are suggesting above has vastly different semantics from the Chromium method.

Other question: the Chromium source says:

> A page's SiteInstance is determined by a combination of where the page comes from (the site) and which frames have references to each other (the instance)‚Ä¶ If the user navigates within a site, the same SiteInstance is used. (https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/content/public/browser/site_instance.h)

‚Ä¶so it doesn‚Äôt seem like comparing the current and pending site instances would accurately tell us whether a page load is happening, e.g. if navigating from `http://example.com/index.html` to `http://example.com/about.html`. Or am I misunderstanding?

You are right, but in electron we restart render process for pretty much every navigation. So the check should be valid and it is just to determine main frame navigation, should be used along with `IsLoading`. This is not the best fix, just want to throw some possible ideas.

Thanks, @deepak1556. I wound up mostly following your advice, but with a couple changes:
- I kept the method named `isLoadingMainFrame()` to reduce confusion with `IsLoadingToDifferentDocument` (since they have different semantics). Can rename if that doesn‚Äôt seem good.
- I wound up pulling `GetLastCommittedURL()` into the equation because it turns out we keep the same site instance on the very first navigation (well, that or there‚Äôs no pending site instance; I didn‚Äôt check which). I _think_ the only instance in which `GetLastCommittedURL()` would be empty is if no previous page had ever been loaded. Let me know if that‚Äôs incorrect.
